subject: Allow compute driver to load correctly
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-02 11:52:13.000000000', 'files': ['nova/__init__.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm/commit/09e797014e6ec2cd734e4f77619d4a150cbf175c', 'message': "Allow compute driver to load correctly

In certain environments the load order can be confused between nova and
nova_powervm (now that nova_powervm has a nova/ source path).

This can cause boot issues where 'No module named cmd.compute' can be
thrown because the python code is looking in nova-powervm/nova for that
driver.

This change extends the declare_namespace code to allow for the other
projects to properly load.

This was affecting the PowerVM CI system and not allowing the systems to
properly load.

Change-Id: I4695814ad9ded96a6bb731b2a47f7050fedd8d85
"}]
commit_message:
Allow compute driver to load correctly

In certain environments the load order can be confused between nova and
nova_powervm (now that nova_powervm has a nova/ source path).

This can cause boot issues where 'No module named cmd.compute' can be
thrown because the python code is looking in nova-powervm/nova for that
driver.

This change extends the declare_namespace code to allow for the other
projects to properly load.

This was affecting the PowerVM CI system and not allowing the systems to
properly load.

Change-Id: I4695814ad9ded96a6bb731b2a47f7050fedd8d85

commit_message:
RGW >= Jewel requires pool names prefixed with zone

When deploying Jewel RGW (10.*) or above, pool names are
expected to be prefixed by the RGW client zone name.

Closes-Bug: 1573549
Change-Id: I01fa558b2f259deb243267ba7d714f7b4df5df75

added_lines: from charmhelpers.fetch import apt_cachedef get_rgw_package_ver(): import apt pkg = apt_cache()['radosgw'] vers = apt.upstream_version(pkg.current_ver.ver_str) return vers def get_create_rgw_pools_rq(prefix=None): """Pre-create RGW pools so that they have the correct settings. If a prefix is provided it will be prepended to each pool name. # Jewel and above automatically always prefix pool names with zone when # creating them (see LP: 1573549). if prefix is None and get_rgw_package_ver() >= '10.0.0': prefix = '.default'

commit_message:
Revert "Clean port dns_name in case of port detach"

This patch breaks any neutron plugin that does not support the extension
dns-integration. With this patch in place when update_port is called with
'dns_name' neutron-server will raise a BadRequest as dns_name is only part of
the api if a plugin is using this extension. Instead we should be checking
if a plugin has this extension loaded and if so  append dns_name: ''

Related-Bug: #1575195

This reverts commit fc66e7eb411eb8e99767c062ab8d0263738d5558.

Change-Id: I817b40892cd414eee281c1f0dad4f4bb6f1d21b2

subject: Identify segments uploaded via swiftclient
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-08 20:42:21.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/test_service.py', 'swiftclient/service.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-swiftclient/commit/4a6fa02c2832086d3ea5f7fff694c844da980928', 'message': 'Identify segments uploaded via swiftclient

...using a new "application/swiftclient-segment" content-type.

Segments uploaded by swiftclient are expected to have a many-to-one
relationship to large objects, rather than the more-general many-to-many
relationship that SLO and DLO generally allow. Later, we may use this
information to make more intelligent decisions, such as when to
automatically clean up segments.

Change-Id: Ie56a3aa10065db754ac572cc37d93f2c901aac60
'}]
commit_message:
Identify segments uploaded via swiftclient

...using a new "application/swiftclient-segment" content-type.

Segments uploaded by swiftclient are expected to have a many-to-one
relationship to large objects, rather than the more-general many-to-many
relationship that SLO and DLO generally allow. Later, we may use this
information to make more intelligent decisions, such as when to
automatically clean up segments.

Change-Id: Ie56a3aa10065db754ac572cc37d93f2c901aac60

deleted_lines: etag = conn.put_object(segment_container, segment_name, contents, content_length=segment_size, response_dict=results_dict)

commit_message:
remove EC2 legacy code

continue of removing legacy ec2 code from nova.
Object 'EC2Ids' has been cleaned up and left as dumb object
with its properties not to break compatibility.
These objects was only used by the ec2-api and s3 services.

UpgradeImpact
Change-Id: If74f840b26f929a981ea8d5c55d5c15a07784237

Pin openstack-doc-tools

support DocBook publishing, pin the version.

commit_message:
Remove glossary handling

The DocBook XML glossary is gone, remove the special support in our
tools for it.

implements bp docbook-removal
Change-Id: Ida2bb926718ae7e03ac2ded120cea99c80147857
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-doc-tools refs/changes/02/311702/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: echo "--glossary: Build glossary"GLOSSARY=0 --glossary) GLOSSARY=1 ;;if [ "$GLOSSARY" -eq "1" ] ; then echo "Generating Glossary" # Use "common" directory as common if exists while migration if [[ -e doc/common/conventions.rst ]] ; then COMMON="common" else COMMON="common-rst" fi tools/glossary2rst.py doc/${COMMON}/glossary.rst fi

Remove feeds not reachable and add script to test feed URLs

The following feed URLs are not longer available:

commit_message:
Add VirtualBMC project under Ironic

VirtualBMC is a utility that allows virtual/fake BMCs to be
created handling the IPMI commands and converting it to calls to the
python-libvirt library. The project was created to allow drivers using
the IPMI protocol to be tested in the Ironic gate.

Change-Id: I24349ce1b5c0332157f1bf8bd0613338a15495e4
Depends-On: Idf02cb28316be1846bb5fa1988c3d47ce6f9c54c

commit_message:
Change kolla to release:cycle-trailing

The openstack/kolla repository has followed the
release:cycle_with_milestones schedule +/- 1-3 days for all
milestones in Liberty and Mitaka except where the PTL was ill
with a root canal that failed causing Mitaka-1 to be tagged
far later then it should have been. In that case, the PTL
added backup release managers (asalkeld inc0 and rhallisey)
so that wouldn't occur in the future.

Now that Doug has proposed cycle-trailing, we can meet that

Depends-On: I783f6f6d55ab33386851910d09bf0e3f0efda404
Change-Id: Ibc6837b46c70c3458f8efdb2e79e7bd3a3b3c189

commit_message:
Drop shotgun repo from fuel project

Shotgun is now independent and should be removed
from the list of fuel repositories.

subject: Update release tags for some Puppet OpenStack modules
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-24 21:57:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/53e7daeeed84cdd09e7ca46c5cc610e36a33d4fd', 'message': "Update release tags for some Puppet OpenStack modules

Each Puppet OpenStack module usually has this lifecycle:

- creation of the module: basic structure
- adding features specific to the component to deploy
- adding functional testing, in integration CI if possible so Tempest is
  run, otherwise in beaker jobs only, so we test basic deployments.

Once the module reachs some maturity (used by our Community, regular
contributions, advanced testing), we start producing releases.

Until now, we have 24 modules that we consider mature enough to release
them.

Our release cycle is following OpenStack releases, every 6 months.
At each release, we create a stable branch and our team manage the
backports.
We have a backport policy [1] and a Wiki page [2] documenting the
modules releases.

We would like to apply for 2 release tags:

1) release:cycle-with-intermediary [3]
Our group commits to produce a release to match the end of the 6-month
development cycle. Mitaka is a good example where we're about to release
in the same time as other projects.

2) release:has-stable-branches [4]
- We cut a stable branch from their last release in a given
development cycle, which is 6 months.
- Our team commits to help maintain the stable branches by proposing
backports for critical issues and reviewing those (we have a lot of
operators and people doing production deployments that need backports,
we're taking care of them).

You'll notice in this patch some modules are not applying, because we
don't consider them mature enough or they don't need releases (some
repositories are not deliverables).

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet/Backport_policy
(2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet/releases)
[3] http://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/release_cycle-with-intermediary.html#requirements
[4] http://governance.openstack.org/reference/tags/release_has-stable-branches.html#requirements

Change-Id: Ic6b539f7db58077f102ba9536c862363a5831d5a

commit_message:
Update release tags for some Puppet OpenStack modules

Each Puppet OpenStack module usually has this lifecycle:

- creation of the module: basic structure
- adding features specific to the component to deploy
- adding functional testing, in integration CI if possible so Tempest is
  run, otherwise in beaker jobs only, so we test basic deployments.

Once the module reachs some maturity (used by our Community, regular
contributions, advanced testing), we start producing releases.

Until now, we have 24 modules that we consider mature enough to release
them.

Our release cycle is following OpenStack releases, every 6 months.
At each release, we create a stable branch and our team manage the
backports.
We have a backport policy [1] and a Wiki page [2] documenting the
modules releases.

We would like to apply for 1 release tag:
release:cycle-trailing

Our group already commits to produce a release to match the end of the 6-month
development cycle. Mitaka is a good example where we're about to release
in the same time as other projects.
Though having a small time window after official release will help us to
produce better releases, because of all dependencies that we have
(mostly upstream packaging).

You'll notice in this patch some modules are not applying, because we
don't consider them mature enough or they don't need releases (some
repositories are not deliverables).

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet/Backport_policy
[2] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Puppet/releases

Change-Id: Ic6b539f7db58077f102ba9536c862363a5831d5a

commit_message:
Add support for booting bare metals from Cinder volume

This commit proposes changes to Nova Ironic virt driver
to support booting from Cinder volume (in tandem with
other changes proposed in Ironic).

Co-Authored-By: Satoru Moriya <satoru.moriya.br@hitachi.com>
Change-Id: I11d37595d11b536bbe0f986a3a814bed2b3a2650
Implements: blueprint ironic-boot-from-volume
Depends-On: Ibf50be735905f868e0d523ab16353a6b5cc300af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/01/211101/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================ Ironic - Boot from Cinder volume ================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/ironic-boot-from-volume This spec captures the changes required in Nova Ironic virt driver to enable Ironic to boot bare metal machines from Cinder volume, when requested from Nova. Problem description =================== Currently, there is no way to request an bare metal compute resource from Nova to boot from a Cinder volume. Ironic doesn't support it too. But with some changes proposed in Ironic ([1] and [2]), it will enable Ironic to boot bare metal servers from remote volume. Ironic virt driver needs to pass the remote volume connection information down to Ironic when spawning a new bare metal instance requesed to boot from a Cinder volume. Use Cases ---------- A tenant can request a bare metal server that boots from a Cinder volume. Project Priority ----------------- None. Proposed change =============== * Whenever an instance that boots from Cinder volume is requested in Nova, it queries the virt driver to provide the volume connectors for the hypervisor. Virt drivers should implement the method ``get_volume_connector`` in the Nova driver API. Ironic virt driver should implement this method which hits the Ironic endpoint ``GET /v1/volume_connectors?node=<node_uuid`` in the Ironic API. Ironic API will provide the volume connectors for the bare metal. If ``ip`` doesn't exist in the volume connectors returns from the API, Ironic virt driver should query Neutron to get the private IP assigned to the MAC address ``mac`` (which is the MAC address of the iSCSI initiator). If ``ip`` is not returned, then it means that storage network is managed by Neutron. * Nova Ironic virt driver should pass the ``connection_info`` of the block device passed to ``spawn()`` method to Ironic. Nova Ironic virt driver should add an attribute in Ironic node's instance_info for each attribute in ``connection_info``. For example, for an iSCSI Cinder volume, Nova Ironic virt driver should write the ``target_iqn``, ``target_lun``, ``target_portal``, ``auth_method``, ``auth_username`` and ``auth_password`` to Ironic node's instance_info. .. note:: The scheduler changes to pick up a suitable bare metal node which can support booting from a particular volume should be taken care in the spec which covers the changes in scheduling mechanism for Ironic virt driver ([3] and [4]). Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- End users can request a bare metal that boots from Cinder volume. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers need to prepare bare metal servers that can boot from remote volume in Ironic. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: rameshg87 Work Items ---------- * Implement get_volume_connector for Ironic. * Pass ``connection_info`` to Ironic node. Dependencies ============ Changes are proposed in Ironic to add APIs to get/set volume information for the bare metal node. Nova Ironic virt driver needs to make use of them. #. https://review.openstack.org/200496 Testing ======= Unit tests will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== [1] https://review.openstack.org/200496 [2] https://review.openstack.org/207337 [3] https://review.openstack.org/194453 [4] https://review.openstack.org/204641

commit_message:
Only set port dns_name if dns extension enabled

Setting dns_name on a port when the neutron plugin doesn't
support the DNS Integration extension causes an error.  This is
breaking the networking-ovn neutron plugin gate job.  Updated
the code to only set the port dns_name if the extension exists.

Change-Id: I45d96ee7c4dfb81014599eeaf4cefcbf864c1332
Closes-Bug: #1575195

commit_message:
Fix possible masters search

OCF RA shall not evaluate "0" UUIDs.
Fix getting UUID by including "wsrep_start_position" as well.

Closes-bug: #1576244

Change-Id: Ide4b43f71f74431fa8017ea05c9ea52c05b96a32
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

commit_message:
Deprecate Nova Network

This deprecates Nova Network as was decided in the Nova / Neutron

commit_message:
Retire kolla-mesos project

The kolla-mesos project has been retired via majoirty vote of the
core reviewer team here:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-April/093180.html

Following the process for retiring a project here:
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#retiring-a-project

Change-Id: Ief32a399d0ff57332864c65d5380269051e24b6b

subject: Ensure floating IPs only use IPv4 addresses
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-15 01:55:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c8d6bff6f2886527f78abee3df600c3025885cba', 'message': "Ensure floating IPs only use IPv4 addresses

Description:
Presently Neutron doesn't validate the address family of floating IP
addresses or the internal addresses they are associated with. It merely
associates the first IP of the floating IP's port with the first IP of
the internal port, unless a specified fixed IP is specified. This can
lead to incorrect or poorly defined behavior when IPv6 is present.

The existing L3 agent implementation only manages IPv4 NAT rules. While
IPv6 NAT and NAT protocol translation are possible, the existing
implementation does not support these configurations.

Presently a floating IP can be created on an IPv6 only external network
or associated with an IPv6 fixed IP, but the L3 agent is unable to bind
these configurations.

Implementation:
When creating and updating a floating IP, only consider IPv4 addresses
on both the floating IPs port and the internal port he floating IP is
associated with. Additionally disallow creating floating IPs on networks
without any IPv4 subnets, since these floating IPs could not be
allocated an IPv4 address.

DocImpact
APIImpact

Co-Authored-By: Bradley Jones <jones.bradley@me.com>
Change-Id: I79b28a304b38ecdafc17eddc41213df1c24ec202
Related-Bug: #1437855

Closes-Bug: #1469322
(cherry picked from commit 4cdc71e7d0e5220a5f12ee2dfea1ff3db045c041)

commit_message:
Ensure floating IPs only use IPv4 addresses

Description:
Presently Neutron doesn't validate the address family of floating IP
addresses or the internal addresses they are associated with. It merely
associates the first IP of the floating IP's port with the first IP of
the internal port, unless a specified fixed IP is specified. This can
lead to incorrect or poorly defined behavior when IPv6 is present.

The existing L3 agent implementation only manages IPv4 NAT rules. While
IPv6 NAT and NAT protocol translation are possible, the existing
implementation does not support these configurations.

Presently a floating IP can be created on an IPv6 only external network
or associated with an IPv6 fixed IP, but the L3 agent is unable to bind
these configurations.

Implementation:
When creating and updating a floating IP, only consider IPv4 addresses
on both the floating IPs port and the internal port he floating IP is
associated with. Additionally disallow creating floating IPs on networks
without any IPv4 subnets, since these floating IPs could not be
allocated an IPv4 address.

DocImpact
APIImpact

Co-Authored-By: Bradley Jones <jones.bradley@me.com>
Change-Id: I79b28a304b38ecdafc17eddc41213df1c24ec202
Related-Bug: #1437855
Closes-Bug: #1323766
Closes-Bug: #1469322
(cherry picked from commit 4cdc71e7d0e5220a5f12ee2dfea1ff3db045c041)

added_lines: def _port_ipv4_fixed_ips(self, port): return [ip for ip in port['fixed_ips'] if netaddr.IPAddress(ip['ip_address']).version == 4] if netaddr.IPAddress(internal_ip_address).version != 4: if 'id' in fip: data = {'floatingip_id': fip['id'], 'internal_ip': internal_ip_address} msg = (_('Floating IP %(floatingip_id) is associated ' 'with non-IPv4 address %s(internal_ip)s and ' 'therefore cannot be bound.') % data) else: msg = (_('Cannot create floating IP and bind it to %s, ' 'since that is not an IPv4 address.') % internal_ip_address) raise n_exc.BadRequest(resource='floatingip', msg=msg) ipv4_fixed_ips = self._port_ipv4_fixed_ips(internal_port) if not ipv4_fixed_ips: 'no fixed IPv4 addresses') % internal_port['id']) if len(ipv4_fixed_ips) > 1: msg = (_('Port %s has multiple fixed IPv4 addresses. Must ' 'provide a specific IPv4 address when assigning a ' 'floating IP') % internal_port['id']) internal_ip_address = ipv4_fixed_ips[0]['ip_address'] internal_subnet_id = ipv4_fixed_ips[0]['subnet_id'] def _is_ipv4_network(self, context, net_id): net = self._core_plugin._get_network(context, net_id) return any(s.ip_version == 4 for s in net.subnets) if not self._is_ipv4_network(context, f_net_id): msg = _("Network %s does not contain any IPv4 subnet") % f_net_id raise n_exc.BadRequest(resource='floatingip', msg=msg) # Ensure IPv4 addresses are allocated on external port external_ipv4_ips = self._port_ipv4_fixed_ips(external_port) if not external_ipv4_ips: floating_fixed_ip = external_ipv4_ips[0]

commit_message:
Enable check for E226

By default, pep8.py ignores E226.
Enabled E226 by adding an ignore clause to tox.ini so that
pep8 by default ignore list gets overridden by what we specify.

TrivialFix
Change-Id: I3efedbec845de7810acd345b98cb302c2247f5bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk refs/changes/56/308756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # By default pep8 ignores [E121,E123,E126,E226,E24,E704]. # To enable E226, added ignore clause and removed E226 from the list. ignore = E121,E123,E126,E24,E704

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/96/310896/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =================== Backup and Recovery =================== Standard backup best practices apply when creating your OpenStack backup policy. For example, how often to back up your data is closely related to how quickly you need to recover from data loss. .. note:: If you cannot have any data loss at all, you should also focus on a highly available deployment. The `OpenStack High Availability Guide <http://docs.openstack.org/ha-guide/index.html>`_ offers suggestions for elimination of a single point of failure that could cause system downtime. While it is not a completely prescriptive document, it offers methods and techniques for avoiding downtime and data loss. Other backup considerations include: - How many backups to keep? - Should backups be kept off-site? - How often should backups be tested? Just as important as a backup policy is a recovery policy (or at least recovery testing). What to Back Up ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ While OpenStack is composed of many components and moving parts, backing up the critical data is quite simple. This chapter describes only how to back up configuration files and databases that the various OpenStack components need to run. This chapter does not describe how to back up objects inside Object Storage or data contained inside Block Storage. Generally these areas are left for users to back up on their own. Database Backups ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The example OpenStack architecture designates the cloud controller as the MySQL server. This MySQL server hosts the databases for nova, glance, cinder, and keystone. With all of these databases in one place, it's very easy to create a database backup: .. code-block:: console # mysqldump --opt --all-databases > openstack.sql If you only want to backup a single database, you can instead run: .. code-block:: console # mysqldump --opt nova > nova.sql where ``nova`` is the database you want to back up. You can easily automate this process by creating a cron job that runs the following script once per day: .. code-block:: bash #!/bin/bash backup_dir="/var/lib/backups/mysql" filename="${backup_dir}/mysql-`hostname`-`eval date +%Y%m%d`.sql.gz" # Dump the entire MySQL database /usr/bin/mysqldump --opt --all-databases | gzip > $filename # Delete backups older than 7 days find $backup_dir -ctime +7 -type f -delete This script dumps the entire MySQL database and deletes any backups older than seven days. File System Backups ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ This section discusses which files and directories should be backed up regularly, organized by service. Compute ------- The ``/etc/nova`` directory on both the cloud controller and compute nodes should be regularly backed up. ``/var/log/nova`` does not need to be backed up if you have all logs going to a central area. It is highly recommended to use a central logging server or back up the log directory. ``/var/lib/nova`` is another important directory to back up. The exception to this is the ``/var/lib/nova/instances`` subdirectory on compute nodes. This subdirectory contains the KVM images of running instances. You would want to back up this directory only if you need to maintain backup copies of all instances. Under most circumstances, you do not need to do this, but this can vary from cloud to cloud and your service levels. Also be aware that making a backup of a live KVM instance can cause that instance to not boot properly if it is ever restored from a backup. Image Catalog and Delivery -------------------------- ``/etc/glance`` and ``/var/log/glance`` follow the same rules as their nova counterparts. ``/var/lib/glance`` should also be backed up. Take special notice of ``/var/lib/glance/images``. If you are using a file-based back end of glance, ``/var/lib/glance/images`` is where the images are stored and care should be taken. There are two ways to ensure stability with this directory. The first is to make sure this directory is run on a RAID array. If a disk fails, the directory is available. The second way is to use a tool such as rsync to replicate the images to another server: .. code-block:: console # rsync -az --progress /var/lib/glance/images \ backup-server:/var/lib/glance/images/ Identity -------- ``/etc/keystone`` and ``/var/log/keystone`` follow the same rules as other components. ``/var/lib/keystone``, although it should not contain any data being used, can also be backed up just in case. Block Storage ------------- ``/etc/cinder`` and ``/var/log/cinder`` follow the same rules as other components. ``/var/lib/cinder`` should also be backed up. Object Storage -------------- ``/etc/swift`` is very important to have backed up. This directory contains the swift configuration files as well as the ring files and ring :term:`builder files <builder file>`, which if lost, render the data on your cluster inaccessible. A best practice is to copy the builder files to all storage nodes along with the ring files. Multiple backup copies are spread throughout your storage cluster. Recovering Backups ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Recovering backups is a fairly simple process. To begin, first ensure that the service you are recovering is not running. For example, to do a full recovery of ``nova`` on the cloud controller, first stop all ``nova`` services: .. code-block:: console # stop nova-api # stop nova-cert # stop nova-consoleauth # stop nova-novncproxy # stop nova-objectstore # stop nova-scheduler Now you can import a previously backed-up database: .. code-block:: console # mysql nova < nova.sql You can also restore backed-up nova directories: .. code-block:: console # mv /etc/nova{,.orig} # cp -a /path/to/backup/nova /etc/ Once the files are restored, start everything back up: .. code-block:: console # start mysql # for i in nova-api nova-cert nova-consoleauth nova-novncproxy nova-objectstore nova-scheduler > do > start $i > done Other services follow the same process, with their respective directories and databases. Summary ~~~~~~~ Backup and subsequent recovery is one of the first tasks system administrators learn. However, each system has different items that need attention. By taking care of your database, image service, and appropriate file system locations, you can be assured that you can handle any event requiring recovery.

commit_message:
Check for worker_service initialization

When stopping the engine check if the worker_service is
intialized or not before stopping it.

Change-Id: I876c2cef4bf6589b9bc45f58b5cd52ed0323c9e9
Closes-Bug: #1572851

commit_message:
WIP: Implement get_vifs_by_instance for neutron API

Listing virtual interfaces via the os-virtual-interfaces API
does not work when using neutron as the network API.

For the sake of feature parity and cloud interop, we should
implement this simple API.

WIP since this probably requires a microversion...

Change-Id: Ia017b2f390814c965e06afbc28235e61a04dd60a
Closes-Bug: #1183436
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/288965/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """Get vifs by instance. :param context: nova.context.RequestContext :param instance: nova.objects.instance.Instance :returns: nova.objects.virtual_interface.VirtualInterfaceList; the fields address, uuid and net_uuid should be set for each VIF object in the returned list. """ params = {'tenant_id': instance.project_id, 'device_id': instance.uuid, 'fields': ['mac_address', 'id', 'network_id']} ports = self.list_ports(context, **params)['ports'] vifs = [] for port in ports: vif = objects.VirtualInterface(context, uuid=port['id'], address=port['mac_address'], net_uuid=port['network_id'], instance_uuid=instance.uuid) vifs.append(vif) return objects.VirtualInterfaceList(objects=vifs)

commit_message:
Implement os-virtual-interfaces for Neutron

Requesting a GET to the os-virtual-interfaces API in Nova fails with a 400 if
Neutron is configured as the network API. We should implement the network API
for Neutron so we have feature parity and interoperability between different
clouds where one is running nova-network and another is running Neutron.

Spec for blueprint implement-os-virtual-interfaces-for-neutron

Change-Id: Ice9a9588f14479ef2b5fc5fc0c9c91ba72d07390
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/76/289576/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Implement os-virtual-interfaces for Neutron =========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/implement-os-vritual-interfaces-for-neutron Requesting a GET to the os-virtual-interfaces API in Nova fails with a 400 if Neutron is configured as the network API. We should implement the network API for Neutron so we have feature parity and interoperability between different clouds where one is running nova-network and another is running Neutron. Problem description =================== Use Cases --------- As a user, I want my application to be able to list virtual interfaces for a given server instance regardless of the cloud deployments choice of a networking backend for the compute service. Proposed change =============== Implement ``nova.network.neutronv2.api.API.get_vifs_by_instance`` by calling the list_ports method in python-neutronclient and filtering by the instance uuid and project. Implement a microversion for the ``os-virtual-interfaces`` REST API GET method such that if the request satisfies the microversion, a list of virtual interfaces are returned (like with nova-network). If the microversion is not satisfied and ``CONF.use_neutron`` is True, return a 400 response as it does today. Alternatives ------------ #. We could choose to be rigid and follow our `no more API proxies`_ stance but this is really a trivial change to make the API work for both nova-network and Neutron deployments (see the WIP change [1]_). It would also allow us to unskip a compute API test in Tempest [2]_. #. If performance is a concern (another call from Nova to Neutron), we could use the ``instance.info_cache`` to get the VIF list, but the results may be inaccurate if the cache is old. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- Implement a microversion for the ``os-virtual-interfaces`` REST API GET method such that if the request satisfies the microversion, a list of virtual interfaces are returned (like with nova-network). If the microversion is not satisfied and ``CONF.use_neutron`` is True, return a 400 response as it does today. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- The user will be able to list virtual interfaces when the cloud they are talking to is using Neutron. Performance Impact ------------------ None besides the call to Neutron to list ports. This could be avoided by using the instance's network info cache, but the results could be incorrect if the cache is stale. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Matt Riedemann <mriedem@us.ibm.com> Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Implement ``nova.network.neutronv2.api.API.get_vifs_by_instance``. * Change the ServerVirtualInterfaceController._items method to check the microversion and if CONF.use_neutron is True. If those are satisfied, get the VIFs via the network API, else return a 400. The nova-network case remains unchanged. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= #. Unit tests for the neutronv2 API change and the REST API microversion change. #. In-tree functional test for the microversion, the network API will have to be stubbed out though. #. Tempest tests such that: #. nova-network should always return a list of VIFs for an instance. #. A 400 is returned when requesting VIFs and Neutron is the networking service and the microversion is less than the version that supports the change to the REST API. #. When requesting the minimum microversion for the change and Neutron is the networking service, the REST API will return a list of VIFs for the instance. Documentation Impact ==================== Update the `API docs`_ to point out the new microversion support with Neutron as the network service. References ========== .. _no more API proxies: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/project_scope.html?highlight=proxy#no-more-api-proxies .. _API docs: http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#listVirtualInterfaces .. [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/288965/3/nova/network/neutronv2/api.py .. [2] https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/10.0.0/tempest/api/compute/servers/test_virtual_interfaces.py#L45 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Newton - Introduced

commit_message:
Provide an updated mission for magnum

This mission and service incorporated in this change
seem to better define what magnum is at its current state
and what the session at seemed to agree upon:

https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-magnum-unified-abstraction

The wording can be adjusted but I think it more clearly
and explicitly defines what magnum is (and will help in avoiding
the confusion for others in the future).

Change-Id: Ice43210a134d0ef93cdc75e3383c6fba839ed2fc

commit_message:
[Trivial] replace logging with oslo.log

oslo.log provides more features and is a fundamental recommended
library to use.

Also the library oslo.log provides compatibility for log levels,
logging namespace is not needed.

Change-Id: I37439260d33024aee46c81f9b1db3130403d220c

revisions:

commit_message:
Only reset dns_name when unbinding port if DNS is integrated

We only set the dns_name on the port if the "DNS Integration"
extension is enabled, so we should only reset it on the port
when unbinding if the extension is enabled, otherwise some
Neutron stadium plugins will fail since they don't expect
the 'dns_name' attribute to be on the port.

Change-Id: I7451fbfad53236e9e147a0387dac45ae97f3e75b
Closes-Bug: #1574565

commit_message:
Force iRMC vmedia boot from remotely connected CD/DVD

This patch forces iRMC vmedia boot from remotely connected
(redirected) CD/DVD using 'ipmitool raw' command instead of 'ipmitool
chassis bootdev cdrom'.

Closes-Bug: #1561852
Change-Id: I606e4d3a630ddc4eed071773afcb5274ee64a439
(cherry picked from commit 03fe93abfe5779f27c0eee5495f189e0104a5184)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/59/304959/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - This forces iRMC vmedia boot from remotely connected (redirected) CD/DVD instead of default CD/DVD. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1561852 for details.

commit_message:
Force iRMC vmedia boot from remotely connected CD/DVD

This patch forces iRMC vmedia boot from remotely connected
(redirected) CD/DVD using 'ipmitool raw' command instead of 'ipmitool
chassis bootdev cdrom'.

Closes-Bug: #1561852
Change-Id: I606e4d3a630ddc4eed071773afcb5274ee64a439
(cherry picked from commit 03fe93abfe5779f27c0eee5495f189e0104a5184)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/60/304960/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - This forces iRMC vmedia boot from remotely connected (redirected) CD/DVD instead of default CD/DVD. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1561852 for details.

commit_message:
Adding "security_group_default_rules" parameter

This patch added "security_group_default_rules" parameter into
"List default security group rules", "Create default security group rule"
and "Show default security group rule details". This value was missed.

Closes-Bug: #1564742

Change-Id: I2ac2d68e85e61a71989bc61f00bc121a0f3bd131
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-site refs/changes/16/300916/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
WIP: DNM: Revert "Skip l2_ovs_agent functional tests"

This reverts commit 7d5b1f8dddd0556220ea9f3baae87e3d69b3020f.

This patch should not be merged right now. It's just to trigger all
native interface tests for functinal-py34 job.

Change-Id: Iedd6f42533cfec642bd1a88b42644b9e14af1199
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/48/306248/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Fix conf file open mode when "tempest init"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-26 21:28:09.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/cmd/init.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/63cb9a3718f394c9da8e0cc04b170ca2a8196ec2', 'message': 'Fix conf file open mode when "tempest init"

This commit fixes the conf file open mode when "tempest init" command
runs. The original open mode "w" truncates its file. We should use 'a'
for updating a file instead.

Change-Id: I033454950cf58615e212d8c9fdf96765cf45c454
'}]
commit_message:
Fix conf file open mode when "tempest init"

This commit fixes the conf file open mode when "tempest init" command
runs. The original open mode "w" truncates its file. We should use 'a'
for updating a file instead.

Change-Id: I033454950cf58615e212d8c9fdf96765cf45c454
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/14/310314/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-21 06:53:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow/commit/bb9f6150e6c4eeab89b3750085906145919d165f', 'message': 'Optimize security group fw rules

Instead of multiple rules build for TCP ALL or UDP ALL rule only

'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-04-21 12:07:10.000000000', 'files': ['dragonflow/controller/sg_app.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow/commit/855da109a885078b848ba4bf14a64e4c8c69cfe5', 'message': 'Optimize security group fw rules

Instead of multiple rules build for TCP ALL or UDP ALL rule only

'}]
commit_message:
Optimize security group fw rules

Closes-bug: #1572503

Instead of multiple rules build for TCP ALL or UDP ALL rule only
one rule will be build for each case.

commit_message:
Create .inc files for rst publishing

-Updated create_yaml_parameters.py to create .inc
files for each section.  The section is based on the
tag name and includes the corresponding methods/rst files.
-Added the database inc files as sample output.

Change-Id: I40bfdeb87ae2330fce280ad33525837361587794
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fairy-slipper refs/changes/14/311214/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. -*- rst -*- ================================== Database instance actions (action) ================================== Resizes instances and volumes and restarts instances. Restart instance ================ .. rest_method:: POST /v1.0/{accountId}/instances/{instanceId}/action Restarts the database service for an instance. The restart operation restarts only the MySQL instance. Restarting MySQL erases any dynamic configuration settings that you make in MySQL. The MySQL service is unavailable until the instance restarts. If the operation succeeds, it returns the ``Accepted (202)`` response code. Error response codes:202,413,415,405,404,403,401,400,422,503,500,501, Request Parameters ------------------ .. rest_parameters:: restartInstance.yaml - instanceId: instanceId - accountId: accountId Request Example --------------- .. literalinclude:: samples/db-instance-restart-request.json :language: javascript Resize instance =============== .. rest_method:: POST /v1.0/{accountId}/instances/{instanceId}/action Resizes the memory for an instance. If you provide a valid ``flavorRef``, this operation changes the memory size of the instance, and restarts MySQL. Error response codes:202,413,415,405,404,403,401,400,422,503,500,501, Request Parameters ------------------ .. rest_parameters:: resizeInstance.yaml - instanceId: instanceId - accountId: accountId Request Example --------------- .. literalinclude:: samples/db-instance-resize-instance-request.json :language: javascript Resize instance volume ====================== .. rest_method:: POST /v1.0/{accountId}/instances/{instanceId}/action Resizes the volume that is attached to an instance. You can use this operation to increase but not decrease the volume size. A valid volume size is an integer value in gigabytes (GB). You cannot increase the volume to a size that is larger than the API volume size limit. If this operation succeeds, it returns a 202 Accepted response. Error response codes:202,413,415,405,404,403,401,400,422,503,500,501, Request Parameters ------------------ .. rest_parameters:: resizeVolume.yaml - instanceId: instanceId - accountId: accountId Request Example --------------- .. literalinclude:: samples/db-instance-resize-volume-request.json :language: javascript Promote instance to replica source ================================== .. rest_method:: POST /v1.0/{accountId}/instances/{instanceId}/action Promotes a replica. If you have set up replication, and the base instance is still reachable, you can use this operation to promote a replica to be the new base instance. This can be useful if you want to make a configuration change to the base instance that your replicas are replicating from. For example, you might want to increase the disk or CPU capacity. If you made the change on the base instance directly, you would need to take the base instance down for the duration of the operation. Instead, you can create a replica, make the configuration change on the replica, and then promote the replica to become the new base instance. For ``instanceId``, pass in the instance ID of the replica you want to promote. Error response codes:202,413,415,405,404,403,401,400,422,503,500,501, Request Parameters ------------------ .. rest_parameters:: promoteToReplicaSource.yaml - instanceId: instanceId - accountId: accountId Request Example --------------- .. literalinclude:: samples/db-instance-promote-replica-request.json :language: javascript Delete replication base instance ================================ .. rest_method:: POST /v1.0/{accountId}/instances/{instanceId}/action Deletes the base instance in a replication set. If the base instance becomes unreachable, you can use this operation to delete the base instance. This operation: - Finds the replica that has processed the greatest number of transactions and picks that replica to use as the new base instance. - Transfers the public IP of the old base instance to the new base instance (which is the newly-promoted replica). - Deletes the old base instance. - Takes all the instances in the replication set and makes them start replicating from the new base instance. For ``instanceId``, pass in the instance ID of the unreachable base instance. Error response codes:202,413,415,405,404,403,401,400,422,503,500,501, Request Parameters ------------------ .. rest_parameters:: ejectReplicaSource.yaml - instanceId: instanceId - accountId: accountId Request Example --------------- .. literalinclude:: samples/db-instance-eject-replica-request.json :language: javascript

commit_message:
Only update port of DHCP agent on removed network

remove_network_from_dhcp_agent should only update the port
for the agent on the network it is being removed from.
Otherwise the code will affect ports that have nothing to
do with the network that is being unbound.

Closes-Bug: #1570347
Change-Id: I6b7df4e640711e8ff4f9dd6edbfa53ad82e44fd2

commit_message:
add test for volume notification to telemetry

Cinder notification to Ceilometer has been supported for a long time,
this patch adds some scenario test for it.

Change-Id: I51f1de0383bee4789722565740230855c03476e5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/86/229386/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Hewlett Packard # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from oslo_log import log from tempest import config from tempest.scenario import manager from tempest import test CONF = config.CONF LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) NOTIFICATIONS_WAIT = 120 NOTIFICATIONS_SLEEP = 1 class TestNotifications(manager.ScenarioTest): @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(TestNotifications, cls).skip_checks() if not CONF.service_available.ceilometer: raise cls.skipException('Ceilometer not available') @classmethod def setup_clients(cls): super(TestNotifications, cls).setup_clients() cls.telemetry_client = cls.os_operator.telemetry_client def _confirm_notification(self, metric_name, resource_id): def _check_sample(): query = ['resource_id', 'eq', resource_id] samples = self.telemetry_client.list_samples(metric_name, query) LOG.debug('got samples %s', samples) return len(samples) != 0 self.assertTrue(test.call_until_true(_check_sample, NOTIFICATIONS_WAIT, NOTIFICATIONS_SLEEP), 'Expected notifications were not received after ' '%s seconds.' % NOTIFICATIONS_WAIT) class TestVolumeNotifications(TestNotifications): @classmethod def skip_checks(cls): super(TestVolumeNotifications, cls).skip_checks() if not CONF.service_available.cinder: raise cls.skipException('Cinder not available') @test.idempotent_id('1560ae6d-acf7-441a-a2f0-53555a69e669') @test.services('volume', 'telemetry') def test_cinder_notifications(self): volume_id = self.create_volume()['id'] self._confirm_notification('volume', volume_id)

commit_message:
Fix NoSuchOptError when referring to conf.neutron.auth_plugin

We already replaced 'auth_plugin' with 'auth_type'[1], now an
oslo_config.cfg.NoSuchOptError will be threw up when referring to
conf.neutron.auth_plugin.

This commit replace the usage of conf.neutron.auth_plugin by
conf.neutron.auth_type.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/keystoneauth/commit/a56ed4218aef5a2e528aa682cea967e767dca923

Change-Id: I0b72f278ba8e28508274079ff284042fb9ea3d64
Closes-Bug: #1574988
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/73/310173/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(ks_loading, 'load_auth_from_conf_options') def test_load_auth_plugin_failed(self, mock_load_from_conf): mock_load_from_conf.return_value = None from neutronclient.common import exceptions as neutron_client_exc self.assertRaises(neutron_client_exc.Unauthorized, neutronapi._load_auth_plugin, CONF)

added_lines: Force-delete share ================== .. rest_method:: POST /v2/{tenant_id}/shares/{share_id}/action Administrator only. Force-deletes a share in any state. Use the ``policy.json`` file to grant permissions for this action to other roles. Error response codes:202, Request Parameters ------------------ .. rest_parameters:: parameters.yaml - force_delete: force_delete - share_id: share_id - tenant_id: tenant_id Request Example --------------- .. literalinclude:: ../samples/manila-share-actions-force-delete-request.json :language: javascript

commit_message:
Test multiple operating systems for barbican::db::postgresql

Change-Id: Ia04c644949cc7998d7f42d28563a9a4747c76e74
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-barbican refs/changes/80/311480/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: shared_examples_for 'barbican::db::postgresql' do let :req_params do { :password => 'pw' } end let :pre_condition do 'include postgresql::server' on_supported_os({ :supported_os => OSDefaults.get_supported_os }).each do |os,facts| context "on #{os}" do let (:facts) do facts.merge(OSDefaults.get_facts({ :processorcount => 8, :concat_basedir => '/var/lib/puppet/concat' })) it_configures 'barbican::db::postgresql'
deleted_lines: let :req_params do { :password => 'pw' } end let :pre_condition do 'include postgresql::server' end context 'on a RedHat osfamily' do let :facts do @default_facts.merge({ :osfamily => 'RedHat', :operatingsystemrelease => '7.0', :concat_basedir => '/var/lib/puppet/concat' }) context 'on a Debian osfamily' do let :facts do @default_facts.merge({ :operatingsystemrelease => '7.8', :operatingsystem => 'Debian', :osfamily => 'Debian', :concat_basedir => '/var/lib/puppet/concat' }) end context 'with only required parameters' do let :params do req_params it { is_expected.to contain_postgresql__server__db('barbican').with( :user => 'barbican', :password => 'md5699e09b3c7579f59869b882716fd7299' )}

commit_message:
Add dependencies for paramiko 2.0

Paramiko version 2.0 has been released. It now uses the Python library
cryptography. Installing this requires additional system packages. This
commit adds in the appropriate packages required by cryptography based
on its documentation [1].

An alternative approach would have been to constrain the version of
Paramiko however the project describes the 1.x versions as relying on
insecure dependencies [2].

The apt packages autoconf and g++ are removed because they are
dependencies of build-essential.

[1] https://cryptography.io/en/latest/installation/
[2] http://www.paramiko.org/installing.html

(cherry picked from commit 1b4550b0b88de17057accab1a9cd149c50ff9631)

Conflicts:
	scripts/bootstrap-ansible.sh

Change-Id: Ia7e0d64214cfd5412ec236ee4bdd6a076821d258

commit_message:
Add dependencies for paramiko 2.0

Paramiko version 2.0 has been released. It now uses the Python library
cryptography. Installing this requires additional system packages. This
commit adds in the appropriate packages required by cryptography based
on its documentation [1].

An alternative approach would have been to constrain the version of
Paramiko however the project describes the 1.x versions as relying on
insecure dependencies [2].

The apt packages autoconf and g++ are removed because they are
dependencies of build-essential.

[1] https://cryptography.io/en/latest/installation/
[2] http://www.paramiko.org/installing.html

Change-Id: Ia7e0d64214cfd5412ec236ee4bdd6a076821d258
(cherry picked from commit 1b4550b0b88de17057accab1a9cd149c50ff9631)

commit_message:
Add dependencies for paramiko 2.0

Paramiko version 2.0 has been released. It now uses the Python library
cryptography. Installing this requires additional system packages. This
commit adds in the appropriate packages required by cryptography based
on its documentation [1].

An alternative approach would have been to constrain the version of
Paramiko however the project describes the 1.x versions as relying on
insecure dependencies [2].

The apt packages autoconf and g++ are removed because they are
dependencies of build-essential.

[1] https://cryptography.io/en/latest/installation/
[2] http://www.paramiko.org/installing.html

Change-Id: Ia7e0d64214cfd5412ec236ee4bdd6a076821d258
(cherry picked from commit 1b4550b0b88de17057accab1a9cd149c50ff9631)

commit_message:
Remove negative test framework documentation

We have a conclusion to remove the description of negative test
framework during Austin summit, details at:
https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/newton-qa-negative-testing

Change-Id: Ia3d36b8d1c8e9721b88dbc35bc350af822b8dc6f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/60/311160/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Newly added negative tests should use the negative test framework. First step is to create an interface description in a python file under `tempest/api_schema/request/`. These descriptions consists of two important sections for the test (one of those is mandatory): - A resource (part of the URL of the request): Resources needed for a test must be created in `setUpClass` and registered with `set_resource` e.g.: `cls.set_resource("server", server['id'])` - A json schema: defines properties for a request. After that a test class must be added to automatically generate test scenarios out of the given interface description:: load_tests = test.NegativeAutoTest.load_tests @test.SimpleNegativeAutoTest class SampleTestNegativeTestJSON(<your base class>, test.NegativeAutoTest): _service = 'compute' _schema = <your schema file> The class decorator `SimpleNegativeAutoTest` will automatically generate test cases out of the given schema in the attribute `_schema`. All negative tests should be added into a separate negative test file. If such a file doesn't exist for the particular resource being tested a new test file should be added.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/45/311245/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Test CredentialsTempest allows for configuring a set of admin credentials in the ``auth`` section, via the following parameters: #. ``admin_username`` #. ``admin_password`` #. ``admin_project_name`` #. ``admin_domain_name`` Admin credentials are not mandatory to run Tempest, but when provided they can be used to: - Run tests for admin APIs - Generate test credentials on the fly (see `Dynamic Credential`_) Tempest allows for configuring pre-provisioned test credentials as well. This can be done in two different ways. One is to provide credentials is using the accounts.yaml file (see `Pre-Provisioned Credentials`_). This file is used to specify an arbitrary number of users available to run tests with. You can specify the location of the file in the ``auth`` section in thethe accounts.yaml.sample file included in Tempest. A second way - now deprecated - is a set of configuration options in the tempest.conf file (see `Legacy Credentials`_). These options are clearly labelled in the ``identity`` section and let you specify a set of credentials for a regular user and an alternate user, consisting of a username, password, project and domain name.Pre-Provisioned Credentials """"""""""""""""""""""""""" Pre-Provisioned Credentials are also know as accounts.yaml or accounts file. Legacy Credentials """"""""""""""""""
deleted_lines: Auth/CredentialsTempest currently has two different ways in configuration to provide credentials to use when running Tempest. One is a traditional set of configuration options in the tempest.conf file. These options are clearly labelled in the ``identity`` section and let you specify a set of credentials for a regular user, a global admin user, and an alternate user, consisting of a username, password, and project name. The other method to provide credentials is using the accounts.yaml file. This file is used to specify an arbitrary number of users available to run tests with. You can specify the location of the file in the ``auth`` section in thethe accounts.yaml.sample file included in Tempest. Eventually the config options for providing credentials to Tempest will be deprecated and removed in favor of the accounts.yaml file.Pre-Provisioned Credentials (aka accounts.yaml or accounts file) """""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""" Legacy Credentials (aka credentials config options) """"""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""""" #. ``admin_username`` #. ``admin_password`` #. ``admin_project_name``

added_lines: Cinder uses a sql-based central database that is shared by all Cinder services in the system. The amount and depth of the data fits into a sql database quite well. For small deployments this seems like an optimal solution. For larger deployments, and especially if security is a concern, cinder will be moving towards multiple data stores with some kind of aggregation system.
deleted_lines: Cinder uses a sql-based central database that is shared by all Cinder services in the system. The amount and depth of the data fits into a sql database quite well. For small deployments this seems like an optimal solution. For larger deployments, and especially if security is a concern, cinder will be moving towards multiple data stores with some kind of aggregation system.

commit_message:
Prevent binding IPv6 addresses to Neutron interfaces

Explicitly disable IPv6 on Neutron created interfaces in the default
namespace before setting link up. Since the default behavior of IPv6 is
to bind to all interfaces as opposed to IPv4 where an address must be
explicitly configured we disable IPv6 on each interface before enabling
the interface. This avoids leaving a time window between when the
interface is enabled and when it is attached to bridge device during
which the host could be access from a tenant network.

Move disable_ipv6() from BridgeDevice to base IPDevice class so it is
usable by all interfaces. Then we explicitly disable IPv6 on veth
interfaces in the default namespaces and VXLAN and VLAN interfaces
created by the LinuxBridge agent.

In addition vlan interface is moved from LinuxBridgeManager to IPWrapper
so it can return an IPDevice object.

Closes-Bug: #1534652
Change-Id: Id879075f2d5ee42f8ff153e813e7519a4424447b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/73/268373/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
